bibl.title: Report on Jose Antonio Viviesca by Henry R. Muller, [1923]

div1.p: Muller describes the liver of a suspected yellow fever case.

div1.head: Report on Jose Antonio Viviesca by Henry R. Muller, [1923]
div1.p:
The liver in this case is characterized microscopically by its
very marked fat content. In the low power each lobule in the section and
every cell of each lobule contains medium-sized fat droplets. These fat
droplets occur several in each cell, closely packed together, and show a
tendency to fuse and form larger drops. They are grouped around the nucleus
and do not push the nucleus off to one side. The other striking change is
the necrosis of more than half the cells of each lobule, as shown by the
very faintly pink-staining nuclei. The nuclei look like ghosts of healthy
nuclei. There seems to be a slightly increased tendency towards preserva-
tion of the nuclei in the narrow zone on the periphery of the lobules.
Owing to the marked fat content of the cytoplasm, not much else can be
said about it. There is a marked “round cell” infiltration of the slightly
increased amount of connective tissue surrounding the bile ducts. An
occasional polynuclear leucocyte is present in this infiltration. Some of
the liver cells, in addition to the fat, contain very fine faint yellow
pigment granules (probably bile pigment.) There are small hemorrhages be-
neath the capsule.

list.item: 1. Marked fatty degeneration of entire lobules.

3. “Round cell” infiltration of portal connective tissue; also
few polynuclears present.
4. Slight increase of portal connective tissue.
6. Minute hemorrhages beneath capsule of liver.
